tossups.question: In Pseudo-Apollodorus' Bibliotheca, Telamon kills his brother Phocus in this manner, leading to his banishment from Aegina. Hermes' companion Crocus is killed in this manner after standing up, leading Hermes to transform him into a flower. A Spartan prince who died in this manner was admired by the singer Thamyris in what was the first case of male love. It's not related to petrification, but a king killed in Larissa in this manner has his throne given to Megapenthes. At a funeral, Perseus fulfills a prophecy by mistakenly killing his father in this manner. Zephyr's jealousy led him to cause Apollo's lover Hyacinth to die in this manner. This book, which emphasizes the universality of the good news, shares its general structure with a later book also addressed to Theophilus. tossups.question: For a real number q, a form of this quantity that equals "1 over q minus 1, all times 1 minus a sum of quantities raised to the power q," is named for Constantino Tsallis (TZAH-liss). An approximation for this quantity includes a factor of "five-halves plus log V over N capital lambda cubed." Rudolf Clausius' (CLOW-zee-us's) first definition of this quantity expressed it, in certain scenarios, as heat over temperature. This quantity is equal to negative k times the sum of "p log p," taken over probabilities p, by Gibbs' formula. tossups.question: A certain sequence of these numbers will always terminate according to Goodstein's theorem. A field in which every element is bounded above by an element of this set has the Archimedean (AR-ki-MEE-dee-an) property. Three first-order statements and one second-order statement appear in a set of nine axioms for this set, which are stated in terms of the successor function S. bonuses.leadin: Massless free scalar bosons are described by a two-dimensional example of these theories. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these theories, which Juan Maldacena (mal-dah-SAY-nah) claimed correspond to anti-de Sitter space.
The AdS-CFT correspondence has been applied to this class of theories, whose tiny one-dimensional namesake objects may explain quantum gravity.

The AdS-CFT correspondence exemplifies a principle named for this technique, which states that the information contained within a volume is encoded on the boundary. Dennis Gabor invented this technique, which relies on the interference between the object and reference laser beams to form a virtual image.

The Mohe Zhiguan quotes a variety of sutras and thinkers in an effort to codify a system for this general contemplative practice often performed in the lotus position.

bonuses.leadin: "Trolls," "ghosts" and "gnomes" are among the phenomena grouped under the "upper atmospheric" forms of this phenomenon, which are more properly referred to as transient luminous events. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this type of atmospheric electrical discharge, which can occur in a "cloud-to-ground" form.

One of the best-known phenomena referred to as upper atmospheric lightning are these reddish-orange discharges, which like blue jets occur above cumulonimbus clouds during thunderstorms. It took until 1994 for them to be photographed, which was done at the University of Minnesota.
Red sprites are sometimes named for being discharges between clouds and this region of the atmosphere. The effects of this region's E layer, or Kennelly-Heaviside layer, are much reduced at night.

bonuses.leadin: This character's father reveals that he was recruited by the League of the Golden Key to fight against evil. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this superhero, whose real name is Tom Mayflower. Dark Horse Comics released a series centered around this hero, but he first appeared in a novel that describes the stories about him in the Amazing Midget Radio Comics, published by the former novelty company Empire Comics.

The Escapist is a fictional superhero created by the title duo of this novel. In this novel, Joe comes to the United States to live with his cousin Sammy after escaping Nazi-occupied Prague in a coffin.
The Escapist was primarily based on this real-life person. In Ragtime, this Hungarian-American escape artist begins to believe that his life's work is meaningless.

bonuses.leadin: Daniel Takawambait (tak-uh-WOM-bay-it) served as the first indigenous pastor in the first of these settlements, where John Eliot first translated the Bible to an American Indian language. For 10 points each:
parts: Natick (NAYD-ik), Massachusetts was what kind of town, where similarly known Indians who converted to Christianity resided?

Many praying towns were depopulated during this conflict sparked by the death of "praying Indian" and Harvard graduate John Sassamon. The neutral Narragansett tribe was nearly destroyed after this war's Great Swamp Fight for protecting Wampanoags (WOM-puh-NO-ags).

During the conflict, this founder of the First Baptist Church in America sold Narragansetts (NAH-ruh-GAN-sets) and Wamponoags as slaves despite long-standing good relations. Four decades earlier, he founded Providence Plantations on land bought from the Narragansett.
answers: King Philip's War [or First Indian War; or Metacomet's War; or Metacom's War; or Pometacomet's Rebellion]
formatted_answers: King Philip's War [or First Indian War; or Metacomet's War; or Metacom's War; or Pometacomet's Rebellion]

bonuses.leadin: The Oxford Calculators' mean speed theorem effectively involved an integral with respect to this quantity. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this non-space dimension, often illustrated in philosophy using an arrow that points in one direction.
The Oxford Calculators' kinematics influenced this Parisian philosopher, who names a thought experiment about a hungry, thirsty donkey equidistant from hay and water.

Buridan helped develop this quasi-Aristotelian kinematic theory, which he illustrated with a thought experiment about a cannonball falling in a tunnel dug through the entire earth. This theory's namesake quantity is a kind of motive force often seen as prefiguring the concept of inertia.

bonuses.leadin: Intense winds can result in so-called "urban" examples of these landforms, which result when tall buildings flank either side of a straight road. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these landforms. A common example of the impact of carrying capacity is the starvation of deer in a "Grand" one of these landforms in Arizona.
Urban canyons heavily contribute to this effect, where the modification of land surfaces leads to cities being, on average, much warmer than the surrounding rural areas.

Negative ecosystem impacts of urbanization can be countered by "rewilding," a common form of which is reintroducing this type of species to an ecosystem. These species are named for their disproportionate impact on ecosystems compared to their biomass.

bonuses.leadin: The Klofsted model argues that deeper voices more often prevail in these events, predictions of which may consider the Rauch Rule. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these events Allan Lichtman and Vladimir Keilis-Borok analyze with 13 "Keys."

Keilis-Borok's algorithms used to process the Keys were originally created to predict these events. Though often unpredictable, seismographs can detect early P-waves that can serve as warnings of these events.

Lichtman jumped into a canal to announce a 2006 Senate run in this state. HBO's documentary "We Own This City" exposes a $13 billion police corruption lawsuit in this state's largest city and discusses 2015 riots after the death of Freddie Gray.
answers: U.S. Presidential Election Outcomes [accept obvious equivalents; prompt on elections alone with "For what office?"]
formatted_answers: U.S. Presidential Election Outcomes [accept obvious equivalents; prompt on elections alone with "For what office?"]

bonuses.leadin: A novel in this specific genre, Erskine Childers's book The Riddle of the Sands, is usually regarded as the first modern spy novel. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this genre of popular British fiction exemplified by the best-known works of William Le Queux (kyoo), whose popularity declined after 1914. Saki's novel When William Came is in this genre.

The Riddle of the Sands was the main blueprint for this first John Buchan novel about Richard Hannay, often considered a work of invasion literature. Mr. Memory was added to this novel's plot in Alfred Hitchcock's loose 1935 film adaptation of it.
The profusion of invasion literature in Edwardian Britain was mocked in The Swoop!, a satirical novel by this creator of Jeeves and Wooster.
answers: invasion literature [or descriptions indicating literature about invading England]
formatted_answers: invasion literature [or descriptions indicating literature about invading England]

bonuses.leadin: Debussy deemed this opera "decidedly the finest thing I know" after hearing its first act at the 1887 Concerts Lamoureux. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this opera whose opening is played "avec une grande emotion" in distorted form in a Debussy piano piece that imitates the banjo after repeatedly interrupting its B section with this opera's "love-death" motif.
Debussy referred to this composer of Tristan und Isolde as "old Klingsor" after the villain of his Parsifal. Despite Bayreuth attendance, Debussy also made mocking remarks about his Ring Cycle.

Punningly, Debussy used the Tristan chord just before the woman in this opera's Tristanesque love triangle declares "je suis triste." Debussy's use of "idea-leitmotifs" in this opera may reflect his love-hate attitude towards Wagner.
answers: Tristan und Isolde [or Tristan and Isolde; prompt on Tristan] (quoted in Debussy's "Golliwog's Cakewalk")
formatted_answers: Tristan und Isolde [or Tristan and Isolde; prompt on Tristan] (quoted in Debussy's "Golliwog's Cakewalk")

bonuses.leadin: In medieval Scandinavia, the star Sirius was called "Loki's torch" since he legendarily took it from this realm to make the winter habitable. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this fiery Norse realm whose sparks first created the sun, moon and stars. This realm's mixing with Niflheim formed the ancestral jötunn Ymir, whose giant skull became the heavens.

Norsemen nicknamed the Hyades "the wolf's jaw," likely in reference Fenrir's mouth being opened during one instance of this action. Skadi holds a venomous snake while Váli performs this action on Loki using his son's guts.

In one myth, Thor turns Aurvandil's frostbitten toe into a star after sustaining this wound. Thor then goes to the sorceress Groa to heal this specific wound, but she fails after hearing of her husband's toe.
answers: rock stuck in his skull [or Hrungnir's whetstone lodged in his head; accept obvious equivalents; prompt on head wound]
formatted_answers: rock stuck in his skull [or Hrungnir's whetstone lodged in his head; accept obvious equivalents; prompt on head wound]

bonuses.leadin: A complex in this city was the site of a black, windowless room where the emperor meditated. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city where many noblemen and warriors were massacred by the troops of Pedro de Alvarado during a religious festival in its "Great Temple."

Tenochtitlan was the primary altepetl (ahl-TAY-peh-tull), or city-state, of this empire, which was ruled by Moctezuma II (MOCK-teh-ZOO-muh the second) and overthrown by Hernán Cortés (air-NAHN kor-TAYZ).
This Nahuatl language term, which means "big house," refers to a subunit of an altepetl. Tenochtitlan was divided into around 20 of these subunits, including Yopico.
answers: Tenochtitlán (tay-NOHCH-teet-LAHN) [or Mexico-Tenochtitlán; prompt on Mexico City] [The complex was Casas Nuevas, the emperor was Moctezuma II, and the "Great Temple" was the Templo Mayor]
formatted_answers: Tenochtitlán (tay-NOHCH-teet-LAHN) [or Mexico-Tenochtitlán; prompt on Mexico City] [The complex was Casas Nuevas, the emperor was Moctezuma II, and the "Great Temple" was the Templo Mayor]

bonuses.leadin: In this technique, a color change often indicates the endpoint. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this chemistry lab technique that employs a burette and can be used to determine the concentration of a substance.
Titrating one of these compounds with NaOH gives multiple equivalence points. These compounds, by definition, have multiple Ka (K-sub-a) values.
At this stage of a titration, the pH is equal to the pKa of the acid.
answers: half-equivalence point [do not accept or prompt on "equivalence point"]
formatted_answers: half-equivalence point [do not accept or prompt on "equivalence point"]

bonuses.leadin: A poem in this language describes "the child who became a giant" and "travels through the whole word without a pass." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this language of Ingrid Jonker's "The child is not dead" and Breyten Breytenbach's The True Confessions of an Albino Terrorist. Tweede Asem, the Dertigers, and the Sestigers were movements in this language.

A time period described in Mongane Wally Serote's "For Don M – Banned" titles this novel by Sestiger André Brink, in which Captain Stolz impedes Ben du Toit and Melanie Bruwer's investigation of Gordon Ngubene's murder.
Afrikaner lawyer Bram Fischer inspired this author to write about a Communist activist who raises Baasie alongside his white daughter Rosa, but dies in prison, in Burger's Daughter.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the color blue in abstract expressionist painting for 10 points each:
parts: In 2022, this artist's painting Untitled (Yellow and Blue) was falsely claimed to have been sold to raise money for Ukraine. Fourteen of this Latvian-American artist's signature rectangular color field paintings decorate a namesake chapel in Houston, Texas.

Freidel Dzubas stuttered "the point is…" on seeing this painting, whose blues evoke its second title feature. A trip to Nova Scotia inspired this painting, the first made with its creator's trademark "soak-stain" technique.

A 1953 entry in this abstract series is subtitled "Blue Eyes." Meyer Schapiro convinced the artist to complete the first entry in this series, which was inspired by prehistoric statues like the Venus of Willendorf.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about political movements named for specific dates.
parts: The 26th of July Movement, which was named for the date when Fidel Castro led an attack on an army barracks, led to the overthrow of this Cuban dictator in 1959.
The 30th of September Movement was a failed coup in 1965 that this man blamed on communists and used to install himself as president two years later.

The 2nd of June Movement was an anarchist group in West Berlin that was named for the date when university student Benno Ohnesorg (aw-neh-SAWRG) was killed while protesting a state visit from this man.
answers: the Shah of Iran [ or Mohammad Reza Shah Pahlavi; or Mohammad Reza Shah; prompt on Pahlavi; do not accept or prompt on "Reza Shah" or "Reza Shah Pahlavi"]
formatted_answers: the Shah of Iran [ or Mohammad Reza Shah Pahlavi; or Mohammad Reza Shah; prompt on Pahlavi; do not accept or prompt on "Reza Shah" or "Reza Shah Pahlavi"]

bonuses.leadin: Vilfredo Pareto claimed that Joseph Bertrand "wrote his article without consulting the books" in discussing the latter's vituperative criticism of a model of this market structure. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this market structure that can be described by the Cournot ("cor-NO") and Bertrand ("bair-TRON") models.
While firms in the Cournot model choose the quantity of goods they sell, in the Bertrand model they choose this value. Demand curves plot this value against quantity sold.
This quantity corresponds to a weighted average of firms' profit margins under the Cournot model. For a given market, this quantity is the sum of the squares of firm's market shares.

bonuses.leadin: After accidentally killing one of these beings who took the form of an otter, the Aesir stole Andvari's gold and cursed ring as repayment. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this race that includes Fafnir, who transformed into a dragon after murdering his father Hreimdar for that stolen gold. Dvalin is the king of this subterranean race.
While dying, Fafnir tells Sigurd of Dvalin's daughters, who preside over this phenomenon. Those dwarves who preside over this phenomenon cursed Andvari to live in the water as a pike.
After Fafnir's death, Sigurd gains this ability by drinking his blood. Sigurd then uses this ability to learn of Regin's plot to murder him, prompting him to kill the last of Hreimdar's sons.
answers: fate of the dwarves [or the dwarves' destiny; accept determining the dwarves' future]
understanding birds [accept listening to birds' speech; prompt on similar answers that only specify animals]
formatted_answers: fate of the dwarves [or the dwarves' destiny; accept determining the dwarves' future]
understanding birds [accept listening to birds' speech; prompt on similar answers that only specify animals]
